articles.headline: Assad’s Forces May Be Aiding New ISIS Surge
articles.snippet: Insurgents opposed to the Islamic State said the group was exploiting Syrian government airstrikes against them to seize areas near Aleppo.
articles.abstract: Insurgents opposed to the Islamic State said the group was exploiting Syrian government airstrikes against them to seize areas near Aleppo.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Building on recent gains in Iraq and Syria, Islamic State militants are marching across northern Syria toward Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, helped along, their opponents say, by the forces of President Bashar al-Assad.

articles.headline: Instagram to Open Its Photo Feed to Ads
articles.snippet: The mobile photo sharing service, which has been mostly ad-free, is opening its feed to all advertisers and allowing them to target its users demographically.
articles.abstract: The mobile photo sharing service, which has been mostly ad-free, is opening its feed to all advertisers and allowing them to target its users demographically.
articles.lead_paragraph: Instagram is cranking up its money machine, and that means a lot more ads in your photo feed.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Lawmakers Press Takata on Propellant in Airbags
articles.snippet: Calling the messaging around the recalls “tortured at best,” lawmakers expressed frustration with both the airbag maker and a federal auto safety agency.
articles.abstract: Calling the messaging around the recalls “tortured at best,” lawmakers expressed frustration with both the airbag maker and a federal auto safety agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Takata, the Japanese auto supplier, has acknowledged that its airbags are prone to rupture and has vastly expanded their recall, it has maintained that the underlying explosive that powers the airbags can be used safely.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Bruised, Herbalife Swings Back at an Accuser
articles.snippet: Both the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman and Herbalife have turned to federal authorities to defend against each other.
articles.abstract: Both the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman and Herbalife have turned to federal authorities to defend against each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: This Wall Street brawl began with a billion-dollar bet.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Climate Deal Badly Needs a Big Stick
articles.snippet: Fruitless efforts to seriously curb greenhouse gas pollution suggest a new approach is warranted — making it costly not to join an international consortium committed to fighting climate change.
articles.abstract: Fruitless efforts to seriously curb greenhouse gas pollution suggest a new approach is warranted — making it costly not to join an international consortium committed to fighting climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few economists are as versed in the global diplomatic effort to combat climate change as Nicholas Stern of Britain.

articles.headline: Huffington Post in Limbo at Verizon
articles.snippet: It is not completely clear what Verizon might want with The Huffington Post or how a relationship between them might work. The future role of the site’s founder, Arianna Huffington, is also uncertain.
articles.abstract: It is not completely clear what Verizon might want with The Huffington Post or how a relationship between them might work. The future role of the site’s founder, Arianna Huffington, is also uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of years, an array of media companies, venture capitalists and wealthy individuals have quietly explored buying a stake in The Huffington Post. The most recent valuation, according to half a dozen people briefed on the matter: about $1 billion.

articles.headline: E.P.A. to Set New Limits on Airplane Emissions
articles.snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to report as early as Friday that greenhouse gas emissions from airplanes endanger human health through global warming.
articles.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to report as early as Friday that greenhouse gas emissions from airplanes endanger human health through global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is set to announce that it will require new rules to cut emissions from airplanes, expanding a quest to tackle climate change that has included a string of significant regulations on cars, trucks and power plants.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Spotify Wants Listeners to Break Down Music Barriers
articles.snippet: Spotify says that because online streaming services let users listen to anything they want, people are increasingly breaking away from rigid genres.
articles.abstract: Spotify says that because online streaming services let users listen to anything they want, people are increasingly breaking away from rigid genres.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, my two children, ages 4 and 2, have suddenly become obsessed with Simon and Garfunkel.

articles.headline: Pink Slips at Disney. But First, Training Foreign Replacements.
articles.snippet: American tech workers in Orlando found their jobs and desks transferred to immigrants brought in under H-1B visas by an Indian firm.
articles.abstract: American tech workers in Orlando found their jobs and desks transferred to immigrants brought in under H-1B visas by an Indian firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The employees who kept the data systems humming in the vast Walt Disney fantasy fief did not suspect trouble when they were suddenly summoned to meetings with their boss.

articles.headline: Pentagon Seeks Easing of Ban on Russian Rockets for U.S. Space Missions
articles.snippet: The ban was meant to punish Russia for its annexation of Crimea, but the military says it still needs the engines for defense and intelligence purposes.
articles.abstract: The ban was meant to punish Russia for its annexation of Crimea, but the military says it still needs the engines for defense and intelligence purposes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Russia annexed Crimea last year, Congress passed legislation that forced the Pentagon to stop buying Russian rocket engines that have been used since 2000 to help launch American military and intelligence satellites into space.

articles.headline: Democrats Wage a National Fight Over Voter Rules
articles.snippet: A lawyer whose clients include Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign is leading a legal battle that Republicans say is a ploy to energize minority voters.
articles.abstract: A lawyer whose clients include Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign is leading a legal battle that Republicans say is a ploy to energize minority voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats allied with Hillary Rodham Clinton are mounting a nationwide legal battle 17 months before the 2016 presidential election, seeking to roll back Republican-enacted restrictions on voter access that Democrats say could, if unchallenged, prove decisive in a close campaign.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Greece and Eurozone Send Positive Debt-Deal Signals
articles.snippet: As the Greek prime minister held crucial meetings in Brussels, the country’s creditors showed a new willingness to compromise.
articles.abstract: As the Greek prime minister held crucial meetings in Brussels, the country’s creditors showed a new willingness to compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece visited Brussels on Wednesday to discuss a bailout deal, signs emerged that the two sides might be edging closer to a compromise.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Education in Kenya Suffers at Hands of Shabab Extremists
articles.snippet: The Somali Islamist group’s deadly attacks, including one involving teachers, have left a painful void in schools and caused dozens to close.
articles.abstract: The Somali Islamist group’s deadly attacks, including one involving teachers, have left a painful void in schools and caused dozens to close.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANDERA, Kenya — In a small classroom at Mandera Academy, a private school, posters with numbers, the Swahili and English alphabets, and geometric shapes hung on the walls as dozens of students crammed together on small wooden desks.
